title: How to Make an Icon in MS Paint and Paint 3D (Full Tutorial)

steps.title: Understand Microsoft Paint's limitations.
steps.content: Understand Microsoft Paint's limitations. Unfortunately, you can't use Paint to create a transparent image in Windows 10; since icons are usually partially transparent to allow for the desktop to display behind them, this means that your image will both be square and use different colors in the final product than you used to create the icon. In Windows 11, however, Paint can create transparent backgrounds. One solution to the transparency issue is to save your Paint project as an image (rather than as an icon) and then use an online converter to turn the image into an icon. When using Microsoft Paint to create an icon, it's best to stick to black and white as other colors can appear distorted in the final product.

steps.title: Open Paint.
steps.content: Open Paint. Type in paint in the taskbar search bar, then click Paint at the top of the Start window. This will open the Microsoft Paint program in a new window.

steps.title: Enable gridlines.
steps.content: Enable gridlines. This will make it easier to draw your icon: Click the View tab at the top of the window. Check the "Gridlines" box in the "Show or hide" section of the toolbar. Click the Home tab to return to the main Paint screen.

steps.title: Click Resize.
steps.content: Click Resize . It's in the toolbar at the top of the Paint window. Doing so prompts a pop-up window to appear.

steps.title: Check the "Pixels" box.
steps.content: Check the "Pixels" box. This is near the top of the pop-up window.

steps.title: Uncheck the "Maintain aspect ratio" box.
steps.content: Uncheck the "Maintain aspect ratio" box. It's near the middle of the window. If your previous canvas size was not square, unchecking this will allow you to create a new canvas size that is the same length on all sides.

steps.title: Set the canvas size to 32px by 32px.
steps.content: Set the canvas size to 32px by 32px. Type 32 into the "Horizontal" text box. Then type 32 into the "Vertical" text box and click OK at the bottom of the window.

steps.title: Zoom all the way in.
steps.content: Zoom all the way in. Since the 32-by-32 canvas is too small to work on, click the + icon in the lower-right side of the Paint window seven times. This will zoom all the way in on your canvas.

steps.title: Draw your icon.
steps.content: Draw your icon. Select a color from the top-right side of the window, then click and drag across your canvas to create your icon. If necessary, you can change your brush size by clicking the Size option in the toolbar and then clicking the correct thickness in the drop-down menu.

steps.title: Remove the background (Windows 11 only).
steps.content: Remove the background (Windows 11 only). If you're on Windows 11, Paint can now remove backgrounds to allow for transparency. To do this, follow these steps: Click on the Layers button at the top of the screen. Notice that the layers for your image will be displayed on the screen. Click the eye icon in the upper-right corner of the background. The background is the bottom-most layer. You'll now see a gray checkerboard for a background, which indicates transparency. The image will not be saved with a checkerboard background.

steps.title: Save your icon.
steps.content: Save your icon. If you want to convert the icon later, just click File , click Save , select a save location, and click Save ; otherwise, to save the image as an icon file, do the following: Click File . Select Save as , then click Other formats in the pop-out menu. Type in whatever you want to name your icon followed by .ico (e.g., a Word icon that is named "Word alternate" would be "Word alternate.ico"). Click the "Save as type" drop-down box, then click 256 Color Bitmap in the drop-down box. Select a save location on the left side of the window. Click Save , then click OK when prompted. If you saved your image as a file type other than .ico, simply open the image in Paint and save a new copy of the image as a .ico file.

steps.title: Understand Paint 3D's limitations.
steps.content: Understand Paint 3D's limitations. Unlike classic Microsoft Paint, Paint 3D allows you to create your image on a transparent background; however, you cannot create an icon file from directly within Paint 3D. Fortunately, you can use ICO Convert to turn your image with a transparent background into a more satisfactory icon file.

steps.title: Open Start .
steps.content: Open Start . Click the Windows logo in the bottom-left corner of the screen.

steps.title: Open Paint 3D.
steps.content: Open Paint 3D. Type in paint 3d , then click Paint 3D at the top of the Start window. Unlike Microsoft Paint, Paint 3D is only available on Windows 10 computers. Paint 3D was first introduced with the Windows 10 Creator's Update in spring 2017. If you don't have Paint 3D, update Windows 10 before proceeding.

steps.title: Click New.
steps.content: Click New . It's at the top of the window.

steps.title: Click the "Canvas" button.
steps.content: Click the "Canvas" button. This box-shaped icon is in the upper-right side of the window. Doing so opens a sidebar on the right side of the window.

steps.title: Click the white "Transparent canvas" switch .
steps.content: Click the white "Transparent canvas" switch . The switch will turn blue , indicating that your canvas is now transparent. If this switch is blue, your canvas is already transparent.

steps.title: Resize the canvas.
steps.content: Resize the canvas. On the right side of the window, do the following: Click the "Percent" drop-down box, then click Pixels in the resulting menu. Replace the value in the "Width" box with 32 . Replace the value in the "Height" box with 32 .

steps.title: Zoom in.
steps.content: Zoom in. Click and drag the slider in the upper-right side of the page until your canvas is large enough to work on.

steps.title: Draw your icon.
steps.content: Draw your icon. Click the brush-shaped "Brushes" tab at the top of the window, select a brush, select a color, lower the brush's size if necessary, and click and drag to draw on the canvas.

steps.title: Click the "Menu" icon.
steps.content: Click the "Menu" icon. This folder-shaped icon is in the top-left corner of the window.

steps.title: Click Image.
steps.content: Click Image . It's in the main window. Doing so opens a "Save As" window.

steps.title: Enter a name for your icon.
steps.content: Enter a name for your icon. Type whatever you want to name your icon into the "File name" text box.

steps.title: Make sure the file format is correct.
steps.content: Make sure the file format is correct. In the "Save as type" box, you should see "2D - PNG (*.png)" listed; if not, click the "Save as type" box and then click 2D - PNG (*.png) in the drop-down menu.

steps.title: Select a save location.
steps.content: Select a save location. Click a folder (e.g., Desktop ) on the left side of the window.

steps.title: Click Save.
steps.content: Click Save . It's in the bottom-right corner of the window. Doing so will save your project as a PNG with a transparent background.

steps.title: Convert an image file into an icon.
steps.content: Convert an image file into an icon. Since your saved PNG file can't be used as an icon, you'll have to turn it into an icon file with a free website: Go to https://icoconvert.com/ in your computer's web browser. Click Choose file . Select your PNG, then click Open . Click Upload . Crop your image as needed, then scroll down and click Select None . Ensure "ICO for Windows 10, Windows 11, 7 and 8" is selected. Scroll all the way down and click Convert ICO . Click the Download your icon(s) link when it appears.

steps.title: Use your icon as a shortcut
steps.content: Use your icon as a shortcut . Once you've saved the icon, you're free to assign it to a shortcut on your computer.
